content.description:
Start at the bottom of a big detached boulder that forms a left facing corner. Head up the corner and gain the top of the block. Move right and head to the next left facing corner. Use the face/corner to head straight up to the top. 

  The route name comes from the route being great for kids. If they have trouble gaining ground on rock - just hug the tree!
content.protection:
Trad: Standard rack. Â The move to top out is awkward and feels at least a grade above the rest of the climbing, but appropriately enough there is a small stump within reach.

 Long static for top rope anchors.
content.location: Obvious left facing corner on the right side of the Basilisk wall.

content.description:
History of this is a little foggy, but climbed by Nick Fern and Matt Ratajczak sometime between 2012 and 2013 for a Top Rope First Ascent.  

  Start below a vertical seam. Gain that and get some good footing before heading straight up to the top.
content.protection: None. Long static rope for top rope anchors from trees.
content.location: About 5 feet to the right of the obvious black streak on the left side of the Basilisk wall.

content.description:
Top rope only unless you free solo. 

  Start 5 feet left of the black streak on "imaginary holds" to the top. In other words, it seems impossible, but the holds are there. May be easier if you're shorter.
content.protection: Long static line for tree anchors.
content.location: Just left of the obvious black streak on far left of the Basilisk wall.

content.description: Start underneath the right side of the large detached boulder about 7 feet up, at a vertical crack. Head up the vertical crack, and gain the arete. Follow it to the top. Great moves.
content.protection: Trad: Standard rack.Top-Roping: Static for TR anchor to trees.
content.location: Far right of the Basilisk wall, on a prominent arete that creates a large left facing corner.

content.description: The face climb between Dragon's Belly and Fafnir. Discontinuous cracks can be used. Easy TR set up.
content.protection: Small gear. Easy TR set up with static rope or gear in the cracks.

content.description: This is a project. Please contact Norm Rasmussen on Facebook or in the facebook group "Powerlinez-Beta Shed" if you've completed this route.
content.location: Just left of The Fuzz - Climbs the face.

content.description: Just right of Chopper Noise. 10ish face climbing, using the flake system to the left is just off limits.
content.protection: Long static for TR anchors off of trees, gear for leading, not sure.
content.location: Below small "arch" made of downward facing flakes about 8 feet off the ground.

content.description: A really painful but fun climb that has an awkward dyno. Start with the vertical knife-edge crack and work straight up past the overhang to gain a moderate edge. The slightly protruding rail to the right is on (I've seen this rail used as a foot for Billy Get Your Guns). Pull a desperate dyno to the extra lumpy hold on the rail (crux). Continue up the chossy face to the top.
content.protection: Same anchor as Billy Get Your Guns. There's a few good trees in the back that require long static (50+ft). Could potentially be trad climbed but would absolutely have a ground fall if you fall on the crux.
content.location: Vertical knife-edge crack under the overhang to the right of the big gap in the crag.

content.description:
Super classic route - fun moves, great pump, good (sometimes marginal) holds, and worth all the effort! 

  Climb up the center of the obvious black streak on the left side of the Basilisk wall on razor holds. Some holds include a half moon and a chicken head. Avoid the moss at the top to the left and top out.
content.protection: None. Long static for TR anchor off trees.
content.location: At the obvious black streak on the left side of the Basilisk Wall.

content.description: The route starts in the vertical hand pockets and goes up left to a small horizontal with slopey crimps and straight up from there. The route can be crumbly due to it not having being climbed a lot.
content.protection: There is a horizontal a little ways up and then more gear options towards the top but it would definitely be a thin lead. Easy to set up a TR from the cliff top.
content.location: After coming up the gulley and having the whole Basilisk wall in front of you, walk to the far left. It is about 20 feet to the left of the route Hashtag, Swag, Yolo which is the black streak.

content.description: Start in blocky alcove below obvious crack that leans left towards the top. Easy start quickly changes to 5.9ish crack climbing (some jams, mostly pulls and liebacks).
content.protection: Standard rack. First piece is pretty high off the deck. I used a 13 nut sideways at one point.
content.location: Just left of the depression in the middle of the Basilisk wall at obvious crack line. Climb that line.

content.description: Starts 10 feet right of TMVG, using another vertical weakness. Head up, and once at the vertical seam move right up to horizontals. Stay left of the small sapling growing out of the diagonal crack and head to the top.
content.protection: No lead yet, use a long static to create top rope anchors off the trees.
content.location: 10 feet to the right of the obvious black stream, directly below the top of the diagonal leaning crack.

content.description:
Up the crack, which goes up to right-facing corner crack. Finish to big left-pointing tree (more horizontal than vertical), which is above obvious right-facing corner with wider crack. 

  Variation: Start up the shorter crack to the right. 

warning: The rock around this sector has not been climbed much yet, and much of the rock is still breakable and loose -- so the belayer and other people should stand far away from underneath the climber.
content.protection:
Leading: normal NY style Trad rack - (though of course not likely to need doubles on such a short route). 

  Top-Roping: Easiest with a long static line from a tree set back from the top of the cliff (perhaps rappel or down-climb a short ways below the top to set the carabiners lower, to avoid drag / abrasion of belay rope running over the top edge).   Or could build an anchor at the top of the route placing multiple pieces of Trad protection gear. 

  For more ideas about setting up Top-Rope anchor, see the area page for this Basilisk sector.
content.location: At the right edge of sector Basilisk is a big right-facing inside corner with a big crazy tree at its top. Left 25 ft from this is a left-facing inside corner with a shallow roof to its left a ways up. Fafnir is the slightly-left-trending crack which is about 15 ft right from the left-facing corner and about 10 ft left from the right-facing corner.

climbs.name: Earth Dragon
climbs.fa: FA TR Dave Barone, FA Jon Crefeld, Nov 2013

content.description:
Begin in some block cracks and gain the "sideways" arch with a sapling growing out of it. Head up and move under and left of the sapling and up the crack. Top out.  

  Can be dusty and/or dirty.
content.protection: Standard rack, sling for the tree. Use long static lines for top rope anchors.
content.location: Right of BGYG on the blank-ish face with the first right and then left leaning crack with a sapling growing out of it. See pictures.

content.description: Starts up in a small alcove to an obvious left leaning crack to the top. It is the first major crack right of TT Arete. If you can bear the sharp rock there are some solid opportunities for jams.
content.protection: Standard rack, eats nuts. Great opportunity for a cordelette off the solid tree growing out of the crack directly above the route. Easy TR set up. Great for gumbos and kids.
content.location: Far right of Basilisk wall at the left most crack just right of TT Arete.

content.description: Center of the Basilisk wall. Scramble up the rocks to the moss covered arete - obviously pointing out of the depression in the center of the wall. First gear is pretty high. Unless the moss reveals something lower, it's not recommended for trad.
content.protection: Standard rack, bring long static line for top roping.
content.location: Dead center of the Basilisk wall in the middle of the obvious depression.

content.description: Start right of small birch. Large block and mossy crack with ferns are off. Follow up to very small under-cling and traverse a bit right to pull small block. Once a top big ledge traverse left to right facing flakes and finish to top.
content.protection: Long static line for top rope anchors.
content.location: Just left of the two large left facing corners, 40 feet right of the depression in the center of the wall.

content.description: Using the left facing flake system head up some easy holds to big under clings. Move up over the under clings staying right of the small sapling in the diagonal crack (crux) and up to horizontals and top out.
content.protection:
Standard rack. It's not very tall. A single rack of cams will suffice. 

  For TR, long static line for anchors will do.
content.location: At obvious arching flake and crack system. About 30 feet right of the obvious black streak.

climbs.name: Billy Get Your Guns
climbs.fa: FA TR Dave Barone, FFA Chaoqing Hou, June 2013

content.description:
Up over right side of roof, then up face to the top. 

warning: The rock around this sector has not been climbed much yet, and much of the rock is still breakable and loose -- so the belayer and other people should stand far away from underneath the climber.
content.protection:
Leading: normal NY style Trad rack, perhaps with emphasis on smaller stuff. 

  Top-Roping: Trees above top of cliff are set a ways back, so it's easiest if bring a long static line for setting up top anchor.   For more ideas about setting up Top-Rope anchor, see the area page for this Basilisk sector.
content.location: Under low roof just right from 15-ft-wide alcove capped by high deep roof.

content.description:
One of the wider walls at Powerlinez, with lots of face climbing, some short cracks on the right. 

  Faces SSW, so often warm on winter afternoons, cool on summer mornings. 

  The flat area not far from the bottom of the cliff can be swampy -- so think about insect protection (or avoidance at times of likely high insect activity). 

Top-Roping: Usually easiest with a long static line from a tree set back from the top of the cliff - (sometimes helps to rappel or down-climb a short ways below the top to set the carabiners lower so to avoid drag / abrasion of belay rope running over the top edge).   Some routes offer the alternative of building an anchor near the by placing multiple pieces of Trad protection gear.   Reach the top of the cliff by scrambling up around the left or right side.
